definitions.definition: a long thin piece of potato fried in oil or fat

examples.text: He was eating a burger and chips.
All main courses are served with chips or baked potato.
I never cook anything grand—we live on chips and baked beans.

definitions.definition: a thin round slice of potato that is fried until hard then dried and eaten cold. Chips are sold in bags and are made to taste of many different foods.
a small flat hard piece of food, often like a triangle in shape, made from maize
the place from which a small piece of wood, glass, etc. has broken from an object

examples.text: This mug has a chip in it.
She had a slight chip off her front tooth.

definitions.definition: a small piece of wood, glass, etc. that has broken or been broken off an object

examples.text: **chocolate chip** cookies *(= biscuits containing small pieces of chocolate)*
The gutted raw fish are smoked slowly over wood chips.

definitions.definition: a small flat piece of plastic used to represent a particular amount of money in some types of gambling
an act of hitting or kicking a ball high in the air so that it lands within a short distance

examples.text: She left herself with a short chip to the green.
He cashed in his chips last summer aged 65.

definitions.definition: a person who is very similar to their mother or father in the way that they look or behave
to be sensitive about something that happened in the past and become easily offended if it is mentioned because you think that you were treated unfairly

examples.text: He has a real chip on his shoulder about not being chosen for the team.

definitions.definition: to be in a situation in which you are certain to be defeated or killed
used to refer to a difficult situation in which you are forced to decide what is important to you

examples.text: I'm not sure what I'll do when the chips are down.
When the chips are down he always finds the courage to carry on.

wordOrigin: Middle English: related to Old English forcippian ‘cut off’.
